comment._content: The tartan trousers makes them lowlanders. Highlanders all had kilts. Hat man appears to be antipodean - I don't think anyone else got a slouch hat. He also appears to be wearing cavalry trousers. Puttees were gone by 1940.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It's a real problem dating armies on manouevers in peacetime because they never throw anything away and have 50 years' worth of antiquated equipment in use until they need to replace it all a week into the newest war.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I can't see any motor vehicles in the other photos in the set - possibly pre-WWI?

comment.author: 16132340@N07
comment._content: Its one of the few army barracks left since the "normalisation" process took effect. As far as I know it may be earmarked for closure in the next few years. Several barracks in my area have closed in recent years. Bessbrook, Crossmaglen and Forkhill to name a few.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: You can find out all about the history of Ballyknler/Ballykinlar here - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballykinler. The camp has been used as a training base for many years both by the Army and RUC (as was) and the base is one of a number which were dotted along the County Down coast - places like Killard Point (which was part of RAF Bishopscourt) which have now disappeared.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
SOme snippets from the (London) Times: May 30 1904
The 1st Batt. Royal Irish Fusilliers has arranged for a march through the territorial district which includes the counties of Armagh, Cavan, and Monaghan. Tha battalion will leave Holywood, Belfast, on June 16 for Lurgan by rail, and its halting places on the march from there will be as follows:- June 17, Portadown; 18th, Armagh; 20th Middletown; 21st Monaghan; 22nd, Clones; 23rd, Castle Sanderson; 24th, Cavan Camp; 25th, Cootehill; 27th Ballyboy; 28th, Castleblayney; 29th, Newtonhamilton; 30th, Newry; July 1, Hilltown; 2nd Castlewellan; 4th, Ballykinlar Camp, where the battalion will go through the summer drills.
Aug 20 1907:
... the 2nd Battalion Sussex Regiment, which is, it is stated, going into camp at Ballykinlar, for the annual field and musketry training
Dec 9 1908
It is understood that the North Irish Horse, of which Lord Shaftsbury is the commanding officer, and the Marquis of Hamilton is secong in command, wil train in the coming season for 24 days at Ballykinlar Camp, county Down. Recruiting for the reiment under the new conditions has been satisfactory so far.
July 29 1909
THE TERRITORIAL FORCE BELFAST OFFICERS' TRAINING CORPS The Belfast University contingent of the Officers' Training COrps goes into camp at Ballykinlar on Saturday fro a fortnight's training. The Commander-in-Chief in Ireland (Sir Neville Lyttleton) has expressed his intention of himself making the annual inspection of the corps during their stay in camp
Dec 4 1920
A number of prisoners who had been detianed at Dublin during the past fortnight have been taken to the internment camp at Ballykinlar, Co. Down.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I think you're right Boer War? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02]  I don't think he's antipodean it's not a true slouch hat since 1903 the Slouch hat is worn with a seven band puggaree, said to represent the six states and the territories of Australia, the soldiers' Unit Colour Patch, Corps or Regiment Hat badge at the front and the General Service Badge (The Rising Sun, on the left brim); and the left brim is folded up and clipped into place.  That hat has only one band, no unit badge and is folded on the right and what the ***** is that jacket he's wearing??

comment.author: 54059458@N02
comment._content: I think the hat belongs to the Irish Yeomenry (North Irish Horse, like it's sister unit the South Irish Horse were cavalry units). Based on info from John Spooner my vote is for the 1908 date. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Yeomanry

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Definitely Scottish troops, possibly militia/reserve. The slouch hat was known as the service dress hat and was withdrawn from regular army use after 1905 although volunteer units continued to use it for quite some time afterwards. This is a photo in the NLI collection of the Waterford Artillery militia wearing similar hats The jacket worn by the man on the right is an 1868 pattern highland doublet and similar to the ones worn by these Royal Scots soldiers Some highland regiments did wear trews like the ones worn by this 71st Highland Light Infantry soldier

comment.author: 66941036@N05
comment._content:
Looking at the photo in its full size, three of the soldiers are from the King's Own Scottish Borderers (KOSB), a Lowland Regiment, as identified by the white worsted embroidered shoulder title of the man in the Scottish (not highland) undress 'doublet' (the type of jacket), as well as the man in the glengarry cap, whose badge is visible.  This ID is then further confirmed by the Leslie tartan trews of the man on the left.  The soldier in the slouch hat is also wearing riding breeches, which seen together indicate that he is a member of the battalion's mounted infantry section, a particularly topical specialisation of that period.

The 'odd man out', is the soldier second from left who is wearing a field service cap (FSC) that was introduced in 1874 and then gradually phased out from around 1902.  His badge (just visible), appears to be a grenade shape (with possibly a coronet over).

Because of the uniforms and the slouch hat (introduced for foreign service in 1902, but also worn at home in the field on manoeuvres) I would date the photo to between 1901-03.

In 1902 the 1st Battalion KOSB were based in Belfast (Holywood Barracks), as part of the"Belfast District" within the British Army's nationwide garrisons.  The 1st Battalion Royal Irish Fusiliers were also based in Belfast at that time and it seems likely to be the unit of the soldier in the 'odd man out' uniform.

It had long been the tradition that every summer the battalions went on annual training camp 'under canvas' (i.e. tented), where they practised musketry (rifle firing) for annual classification, and tactical manoeuvres.  The camp would usually conclude with a Brigade Exercise or Scheme, when all the battalions would come together for a combined manoeuvre.  That is very likely what is seen in this photo, where a small group of soldiers are carrying out "cookhouse fatigues" and specifically "spud bashing" (potato peeling).  To bear this out, two of the men are wearing fatigue jackets designed for dirty work.  

All the other photos in the series show the tented camp as was typically laid out and known as 'Lines', of which there were 3 types, company, or troop/squadron lines, gun, or transport lines, and horse lines.  The terminology used depended of course on whether they were artillery, cavalry, or infantry lines.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Ballykinler has extensive ranges which would have been used for classification for rifle shooting etc and the place is sufficently remote and large enough to accommodate a large exercise. Interestingly the whole area is suitably vague on Google Maps. Even during the Troubles it was used for training purposes.
